lclpy.termination package¶

Submodules¶

lclpy.termination.abstract_termination_criterion module¶

class lclpy.termination.abstract_termination_criterion.AbstractTerminationCriterion¶

Bases: abc.ABC

Template to create termination criterions.

check_first_value(value)¶

Function that should be called once before the main loop.

Parameters

value (int or float) – Is the evaluation value of the initial problem.

check_new_value(value)¶

Checks a value.

Does not need to be used or implemented.

Parameters

value (int or float) – A value from the evaluation function.

check_variable(variable)¶

Checks a variable specific to an implementation.

Does not need to be used or implemented

Parameters

variable – The value of a certain value of a specific algorithm.

iteration_done()¶

Function to be called after every iteration.

Does not need to be used or implemented.

abstract keep_running()¶

Function to determine if the algorithm needs to continue running

Returns

The function returns true if the algorithm has to continue running, if the function returns false the algorithm needs to stop running.

Return type

bool

reset()¶

Resets the object back to it’s state after init.

start_timing()¶

Starts an internal timer if needed.

Does not need to be used or implemented.

lclpy.termination.always_true_criterion module¶

class lclpy.termination.always_true_criterion.AlwaysTrueCriterion¶

Bases: lclpy.termination.abstract_termination_criterion.AbstractTerminationCriterion

Termination criterion that will never terminate an algorithm.

This criterion is only meant to be used as a default termination criterion in algorithms that will stop iterating when no improvement is found. Don’t use it in any other case.

keep_running()¶

function to determine if the algorithm needs to continue running.

Returns

Will always be True.

Return type

bool

reset()¶

Resets the object back to it’s state after init.

lclpy.termination.max_iterations_termination_criterion module¶

class lclpy.termination.max_iterations_termination_criterion.MaxIterationsTerminationCriterion(max_iterations=1000)¶

Bases: lclpy.termination.abstract_termination_criterion.AbstractTerminationCriterion

Termination criterion to terminate after a set amount of iterations.

Parameters

max_iterations (int, optional) – The maximal amount of iterations. The default is 1000 iterations.

_max_iterations¶

The maximal amount of iterations.

Type

int

_iterations¶

The amount of iterations.

Type

int

Examples

Default amount of iterations:

50 iterations:

iteration_done()¶

function to be called after every iteration.

Increments _iterations by 1.

keep_running()¶

function to determine if the algorithm needs to continue running.

Returns

The function returns true if the amount of iteration is smaller than max_iterations, if the function returns false the amount of iterations is bigger than max_iterations

Return type

bool

reset()¶

Resets the object back to it’s state after init.

Examples

Default amount of iterations:

lclpy.termination.max_seconds_termination_criterion module¶

class lclpy.termination.max_seconds_termination_criterion.MaxSecondsTerminationCriterion(max_seconds=60)¶

Bases: lclpy.termination.abstract_termination_criterion.AbstractTerminationCriterion

Termination criterion to terminate after a set amount of seconds.

Note that this terminationcriterion isn’t exact. It will only terminate the algorithm after iterating longer than the set time AND if an iteration is finished. The extra time that the algorithm will run depends on the duration of the last iteration.

Parameters

max_seconds (int or float, optional) – The maximal amount of seconds passed. The default is 60 seconds.

_max_seconds¶

The maximal amount of seconds passed.

Type

int or float

_seconds¶

The amount of seconds passed since the start of the iterations

Type

float

_start¶

The moment when the time starts to be measured in seconds measured from the epoch.

Type

float

Examples

Running for 60 seconds (default):

Running for 3 seconds:

iteration_done()¶

function to be called after every iteration

Sets _seconds to be the difference between the current time and the start time.

keep_running()¶

function to determine if an algorithm needs to continue running

Returns

The function returns true if the amount of time passed is smaller than max_seconds, if the function returns false the amount of time passed is bigger than max_seconds

Return type

bool

reset()¶

Resets the object back to it’s state after init.

Examples

Running for 3 seconds:

start_timing()¶

function to be called before the iterations

Sets _start to the current time in seconds from the epoch.

lclpy.termination.min_temperature_termination_criterion module¶

class lclpy.termination.min_temperature_termination_criterion.MinTemperatureTerminationCriterion(min_temperature=10)¶

Bases: lclpy.termination.abstract_termination_criterion.AbstractTerminationCriterion

A termination criterion for use with a simulated annealing algorithm.

This termination criterion ends the algorithm if the current temperature is lower than the minimal temperature.

Parameters

min_temperature (int, optional) – The minimal temperature. The default is 10.

min_temperature¶

The minimal temperature.

Type

int

_run¶

True if no temperature lower than the minimal has been encountered, False if a temperature lower than the minimal has been encountered.

Type

bool

Examples

A simple example of the default behaviour:

Example with a minimal temperature of 100:

check_variable(current_temperature)¶

Checks if the current temperature is lower than the minimal temperature.

This function should always be called if the temperature is lowered.

Parameters

current_temperature (int or float) – The current temperature of the algorithm.

keep_running()¶

function to determine if the algorithm needs to continue running.

Returns

The function returns true if the current temperature is higher than or equal to the minimal temperature, else it returns false.

Return type

bool

reset()¶

Resets the object back to it’s state after init.

Examples:

A simple example with the default min_temperature:

lclpy.termination.multi_and_criterion module¶

class lclpy.termination.multi_and_criterion.MultiAndCriterion(criteria)¶

Bases: lclpy.termination.multi_criterion.MultiCriterion

Class to use multiple terminationcriteria at once.

Parameters

criteria (list or tuple of AbstractTerminationCriterion) – An iterable object containing the intialised termination criterions one wishes to use.

criteria¶

An iterable object containing the intialised termination criterions one wishes to use.

Type

list or tuple of AbstractTerminationCriterion

Examples

3 termination criteria are used, three tests are done to ensure that all three criterions are capable of stopping the iterating correctly.

MaxSecondsTerminationCriterion stops the iterating:

MaxIterationsTerminationCriterion stops the iterating:

NoImprovementTerminationCriterion stops the iterating:

keep_running()¶

function to determine if the algorithm needs to continue running.

Returns

The function returns true if the algorithm has to continue running, if the function returns false the algorithm needs to stop running. If all the composing termination criterions return False if their keep_running method is called, this method will return False. Else the method will return True.

Return type

bool

class lclpy.termination.multi_criterion.MultiCriterion(criteria)¶

Examples

3 termination criteria are used, three tests are done to ensure that all three criterions are capable of stopping the iterating correctly.

MaxSecondsTerminationCriterion stops the iterating:

MaxIterationsTerminationCriterion stops the iterating:

NoImprovementTerminationCriterion stops the iterating:

check_new_value(value)¶

Checks a value.

Parameters

value (int or float) – A value from the evaluation function.

check_variable(variable)¶

Checks a variable specific to an implementation.

Does not need to be used or implemented

Parameters

variable – The value of a certain value of a specific algorithm.

iteration_done()¶

function to be called after every iteration.

keep_running()¶

function to determine if the algorithm needs to continue running.

Returns

The function returns true if the algorithm has to continue running, if the function returns false the algorithm needs to stop running. If one or more of the composing termination criterions returns False if its keep_running method is called, this method will return False. Else the method will return True.

Return type

bool

reset()¶

Resets the object back to it’s state after init.

Examples

MaxIterationsTerminationCriterion stops the iterating:

start_timing()¶

Starts an internal timer if needed.

lclpy.termination.must_improve_termination_criterion module¶

class lclpy.termination.must_improve_termination_criterion.MustImproveTerminationCriterion(minimise=True)¶

Bases: lclpy.termination.abstract_termination_criterion.AbstractTerminationCriterion

Criterion to terminate after an iteration without improvement.

Parameters

minimise (bool, optional) – If the goal is to minimise the evaluation function, this should be True. If the goal is to maximise the evaluation function, this should be False. The default is True.

_old_best_value¶

The last value. Is initialised as infinite (minimise = True) or minus infinite (minimise = False)

Type

int

_function¶

The function used to judge if a value is an improvement.

Type

function

_run¶

True if no worse value has been encountered, False if this isn’t the case.

Type

bool

Examples

Smaller values are considered improvements(default). 8 iterations with improvement. After that there are no more improvements. The dataset eval_values is hardcoded:

Bigger values are considered improvements. 5 iterations with improvement. After that there are no more improvements. The dataset eval_values is hardcoded:

check_new_value(value)¶

function to be called after every calculation of the evaluation function.

Parameters

value (int or long or float) – Is the new evaluation value of a solution.

keep_running()¶

function to determine if the algorithm needs to continue running

Returns

The function returns True if there hasn’t been encountered a non-improving value. The function returns False if a non-improving value is encountered.

Return type

bool

reset()¶

Resets the object back to it’s state after init.

Examples

Smaller values are considered improvements(default). 8 iterations with improvement. After that there are no more improvements. The dataset eval_values is hardcoded. After this, the criterion is resetted and the loop is repeated:

lclpy.termination.no_improvement_termination_criterion module¶

class lclpy.termination.no_improvement_termination_criterion.NoImprovementTerminationCriterion(max_iterations=100, minimise=True)¶

Bases: lclpy.termination.abstract_termination_criterion.AbstractTerminationCriterion

Criterion to terminate after a set amount of iterations without improvement.

Parameters

  • max_iterations (int, optional) – The maximal amount of iterations without improvement. The default is 100 iterations.

  • minimise (bool, optional) – If the goal is to minimise the evaluation function, this should be True. If the goal is to maximise the evlauation function, this should be False. The default is True.

_max_iterations¶

The maximal amount of iterations without improvement.

Type

int

_iterations¶

The amount of iterations with no improvement.

Type

int

_run¶

Will be True if the maximal amount of iterations without improvement hasn’t been reached yet, will be false if this isn’t the case.

Type

bool

_old_best_value¶

The last best value. Is initialised as minus infinite (improvement_is_bigger = True) or infinite (improvement_is_bigger = False)

Type

int

_function¶

The function used to judge if a value is an improvement.

Type

function

Examples

Default amount of iterations without improvement (100), always checking the new value. Smaller values are considered improvements(default). The dataset eval_values is generated. (1 improvement, 99 cases without improvement, 1 improvement, 110 cases without improvement) After this the iterations start:

3 iterations without improvement, only checking improved values. Smaller values are considered improvements(default). The dataset eval_values is hardcoded:

Default amount of iterations without improvement (100). Bigger values are considered improvements. The dataset eval_values is generated. (1 improvement, 99 cases without improvement, 1 improvement, 110 cases without improvement) After this the iterations start:

3 iterations without improvement. Bigger values are considered improvements. The dataset eval_values is hardcoded:

check_first_value(value)¶

Function that should be called once before the main loop.

Parameters

value (int or float) – Is the evaluation value of the initial solution.

check_new_value(value)¶

Function to be called after every improvement of the evaluation function.

It’s also possible to call this function every time when the evaluation value is calculated without ill effects.

Parameters

value (int or float) – Is the best evaluation value found for a solution or the new evaluation value of a solution. It does not matter which one is used.

iteration_done()¶

Function to be called after every iteration.

Increments _iterations by 1.

keep_running()¶

Function to determine if the algorithm needs to continue running.

Returns

The function returns true if the amount of iterations is smaller than _max_iterations, if the function returns false the amount of iterations is bigger than max_iterations

Return type

bool

reset()¶

Resets the object back to it’s state after init.

Examples

3 iterations without improvement. Bigger values are considered improvements. The dataset eval_values is hardcoded. After this, the criterion is resetted and the loop is repeated:

Module contents¶

This package contains a template for termination criterions and implementations of said template.

lclpy
